author: MattPennerVVUSD
body:
**Issue:**
On an Azure AD joined device, when running commands such as get-ADUser or get-ADGroup the initial query is very fast.  However, when storing the results in a variable and attempting to view them the domain controller is contacted for each and every single result, causing massive delays for processing records.

This does not occur on a standard domain joined device.  Both devices are on the same physical wired network within the organization.

With the initial query ran and results cached, if the network adapter is disabled traversing the results happens instantly as would be expected.  When viewing the difference between those records returned with a live network and those without the results returned with a live network have five additional blank attributes:

- WriteDebugStream
- WriteErrorStream
- WriteInformationStream
- WriteVerboseStream
- WriteWarningStream

Not sure why traversing the records would cause additional network activity and what these fields are to represent.

**Expected Behavior:**
The code should operate the same whether using a domain joined device or an Azure AD joined device.

**How to Replicate:**
Running the following code on a domain joined PC works fine.  Running the same code on an Azure AD joined PC has the issue.
```
$var = get-ADUser -filter * -Server SomeDCServerName
$var | Select -First 10

```

**PowerShell Version:**
Tested on 5.1.19041.610 and 2021.2.2

**Resources:**
Please check out the following [StackOverflow issue ](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60418494/slow-get-aduser-query#)and [Reddit thread ](https://www.reddit.com/r/PowerShell/comments/mc6gng/ad_powershell_question_writestream_properites)for additional info on users experiencing this.

comments.body: Hi @daxian-dbw, I finally had a chance to test out your suggestion.  Running `$result = $var | Select -First 10` immediately returned, however, when I did a simple select on `$result` I received the same experience.  Running the query and storing that in `$result` is quick, but attempting to iterate over the results causes the formatting to kick in.

comments.author: MattPennerVVUSD
comments.body: Is it possible to disable the formatting system as a workaround in the mean time?
